title: Hundreds of Commonwealth Games athletes who refused to return home have asylum applications rejected
text:
Hundreds of athletes who travelled to Australia to compete in the Commonwealth Games have applied to stay or have simply disappeared.

At least 230 athletes and officials - who are overwhelmingly from Africa - lodged applications for protection visas but 217 have been denied.

A total of 204 have lodged appeals with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to stay in the country, while many athletes vanished before or during the Games.

The ordeal has cost Australian taxpayers an estimated $2million.

A third of the Cameroonian team at the Commonwealth Games have vanished, including weightlifter Arcangeline Fouodji Sonkbou (pictured)

At least 230 athletes and officials - who are overwhelmingly from Africa - lodged applications for protection visas but 217 have been denied (pictured: athletes from South Africa)

At least four appeals have been rejected, according to the Department of Home Affairs documents obtained by The Courier-Mail.

Only six of the 230 athletes have officials have been sent home and one is being held in a detention centre.

Official documents found 17 'unlawful non-citizens' that took part in the Games are still in Australia, 14 of which were from Ghana and Rwanda.

A total of 13 have disappeared, while four are in detention.

A third of the Cameroonian team had vanished, including weightlifters Olivier Matam Matam, Arcangeline Fouodji Sonkbou and Petit Minkoumba.

Boxers Ndzie Tchoyi, Simplice Fotsala, Fokou Arsene, Christelle Ndiag and Yombo Ulrich have also gone missing.

Rwanda's weightlifting coach fled the games during a toilet break at Carrara Stadium.

Rwanda's weightlifting coach fled the games during a toilet break and Petit Minkoumba (pictured) from Cameroon has also gone missing

To keep one person in detention costs $350,000 a year, according to a 2018 Refugee Council of Australia report.

Asylum seekers living in Australia costs over $103,000 and $10,221.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted the Department of Home Affairs for further comment.
